bestBHT.bht: Jesus wept, revealing his humanity and teaching us moderation in our tears. His tears signify his perfect oneness with us and the impact of sin on humanity. In this moment of profound sorrow, Jesus exemplifies compassion as a tender friend, emphasizing the power of tears in times of deep grief. These two words carry immense meaning, expressing empathy for those in tears and the consequence of sin on human nature.

Henry Alford: He wept, as allowing nature to manifest herself:.... there again he rebukes the affections." Euthymius.
Only he assigns a didactic purpose, to teach us moderation in our tears...
I should rather believe the self-restraint to have been exercised as a preparation for what followed.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Jesus wept—This beautifully conveys the sublime brevity of the two original words.
What a seal of His perfect oneness with us in the most redeeming feature of our stricken humanity!
Who can doubt that in His ear every feature of the scene proclaimed that stern law of the Kingdom, 'The wages of sin is death'.
Albert Barnes: Jesus wept - It has been remarked that this is the shortest verse in the Bible; but it is exceedingly important and tender.
It shows the Lord Jesus as a friend, a tender friend, and evinces his character as a man.
Marvin Vincent: The very Gospel in which the deity of Jesus is most clearly asserted, is also that which makes us best acquainted with the profoundly human side of His life" (Godet).
Archibald T. Robertson: Often all that we can do is to shed tears in grief too deep for words.
This is the shortest verse in the Bible, but no verse carries more meaning in it.
John Gill: Jesus wept." - This shows him to be truly and really man, subject to like passions, only without sin.
As he was meditating upon the state of his friend Lazarus, the distress his two sisters were in." - The distress his two sisters were in.
The greater damnation that would befall the Jews then present, who, notwithstanding the miracle, would not believe in him." - The greater damnation that would befall the Jews then present.
John Wesley: Jesus wept — Out of sympathy with those who were in tears all around him...
...as well as from a deep sense of the misery sin had brought upon human nature.

bhtAttempts.bht: In this verse, we see Jesus weeping, not only as a display of his humanity but also as a means to teach us moderation in our own grief and to prepare for what was to come. His tears demonstrate his perfect oneness with us, the full understanding of the wages of sin being death. This brief verse carries profound meaning, as it portrays Jesus as a truly compassionate friend and highlights the power of tears in times of indescribable sorrow. In this moment, Jesus not only empathizes with those around him but also laments the misery that sin has brought upon humanity.

Jesus wept, displaying his humanity and teaching us moderation in our own grief. The brevity of these two words beautifully conveys his perfect oneness with us and the reality that sin leads to death. In this moment of profound sorrow, Jesus shows himself to be a compassionate friend, emphasizing the power of tears when words fail. Through his tears, he empathizes with the distress of those around him and mourns the misery caused by sin.

Jesus wept, allowing nature to manifest itself and rebuking the affections, teaching us to moderate our tears. His tears reveal his perfect oneness with us in our suffering humanity and the wages of sin being death. They show him as a tender friend, deeply empathizing with our grief, and shedding tears when words are inadequate. The brevity of this verse carries profound meaning, emphasizing the compassionate and profoundly human side of Jesus, while highlighting the power of tears in times of unspeakable sorrows.

Jesus wept, allowing nature to manifest itself and rebuking the affections. His tears reveal the perfect oneness with us in our suffering humanity and the wages of sin being death. They emphasize the compassionate and profoundly human side of Jesus, highlighting the power of tears in times of unspeakable sorrows. His tears as a tender friend teach us to moderate our own tears and empathize with the distress of others. These two simple words carry profound meaning, conveying deep empathy and the indescribable impact of tears.

Jesus wept, revealing his humanity and teaching us moderation in our tears. His tears signify his perfect oneness with us and the impact of sin on humanity. In this moment of profound sorrow, Jesus exemplifies compassion as a tender friend, emphasizing the power of tears in times of deep grief. These two words carry immense meaning, expressing empathy for those in tears and the consequence of sin on human nature.
